t: Luke 15
The Parable of the Lost Sheep
Now*p the tax collectors and sinners were all drawing near to hear him.
And the Pharisees and the scribes grumbled, saying, “This man receives sinners and eats with them.”
So*p he told them this parable:

“What*r man*r of*r you,*r having*r a*r hundred*r sheep,*r if*r he*r has*r lost*r one*r of*r them,*r does*r not*r leave*r the*r ninety-nine*r in*r the*r open*r country,*r and*r go*r after*r the*r one*r that*r is*r lost,*r until*r he*r finds*r it?*r
And*r when*r he*r has*r found*r it,*r he*r lays*r it*r on*r his*r shoulders,*r rejoicing.*r

And*r when*r he*r comes*r home,*r he*r calls*r together*r his*r friends*r and*r his*r neighbors,*r saying*r to*r them,*r ‘Rejoice*r with*r me,*r for*r I*r have*r found*r my*r sheep*r that*r was*r lost.’*r
Just*r so,*r I*r tell*r you,*r there*r will*r be*r more*r joy*r in*r heaven*r over*r one*r sinner*r who*r repents*r than*r over*r ninety-nine*r righteous*r persons*r who*r need*r no*r repentance.*r
The Parable of the Lost Coin

“Or*rp what*r woman,*r having*r ten*r silver*r coins,*r if*r she*r loses*r one*r coin,*r does*r not*r light*r a*r lamp*r and*r sweep*r the*r house*r and*r seek*r diligently*r until*r she*r finds*r it?*r
And*r when*r she*r has*r found*r it,*r she*r calls*r together*r her*r friends*r and*r neighbors,*r saying,*r ‘Rejoice*r with*r me,*r for*r I*r have*r found*r the*r coin*r that*r I*r had*r lost.’*r
Just*r so,*r I*r tell*r you,*r there*r is*r joy*r before*r the*r angels*r of*r God*r over*r one*r sinner*r who*r repents.”*r
The Parable of the Prodigal Son
And*p he said, “There*r was*r a*r man*r who*r had*r two*r sons.*r

And*r the*r younger*r of*r them*r said*r to*r his*r father,*r ‘Father,*r give*r me*r the*r share*r of*r property*r that*r is*r coming*r to*r me.’*r And*r he*r divided*r his*r property*r between*r them.*r

Not*r many*r days*r later,*r the*r younger*r son*r gathered*r all*r he*r had*r and*r took*r a*r journey*r into*r a*r far*r country,*r and*r there*r he*r squandered*r his*r property*r in*r reckless*r living.*r
And*r when*r he*r had*r spent*r everything,*r a*r severe*r famine*r arose*r in*r that*r country,*r and*r he*r began*r to*r be*r in*r need.*r
So*r he*r went*r and*r hired*r himself*r out*r to*r one*r of*r the*r citizens*r of*r that*r country,*r who*r sent*r him*r into*r his*r fields*r to*r feed*r pigs.*r
And*r he*r was*r longing*r to*r be*r fed*r with*r the*r pods*r that*r the*r pigs*r ate,*r and*r no*r one*r gave*r him*r anything.*r
“But*rp when*r he*r came*r to*r himself,*r he*r said,*r ‘How*r many*r of*r my*r father’s*r hired*r servants*r have*r more*r than*r enough*r bread,*r but*r I*r perish*r here*r with*r hunger!*r
I*r will*r arise*r and*r go*r to*r my*r father,*r and*r I*r will*r say*r to*r him,*r “Father,*r I*r have*r sinned*r against*r heaven*r and*r before*r you.*r
I*r am*r no*r longer*r worthy*r to*r be*r called*r your*r son.*r Treat*r me*r as*r one*r of*r your*r hired*r servants.”’*r

And*r he*r arose*r and*r came*r to*r his*r father.*r But*r while*r he*r was*r still*r a*r long*r way*r off,*r his*r father*r saw*r him*r and*r felt*r compassion,*r and*r ran*r and*r embraced*r him*r and*r kissed*r him.*r
And*r the*r son*r said*r to*r him,*r ‘Father,*r I*r have*r sinned*r against*r heaven*r and*r before*r you.*r I*r am*r no*r longer*r worthy*r to*r be*r called*r your*r son.’*r
But*r the*r father*r said*r to*r his*r servants,*r ‘Bring*r quickly*r the*r best*r robe,*r and*r put*r it*r on*r him,*r and*r put*r a*r ring*r on*r his*r hand,*r and*r shoes*r on*r his*r feet.*r
And*r bring*r the*r fattened*r calf*r and*r kill*r it,*r and*r let*r us*r eat*r and*r celebrate.*r
For*r this*r my*r son*r was*r dead,*r and*r is*r alive*r again;*r he*r was*r lost,*r and*r is*r found.’*r And*r they*r began*r to*r celebrate.*r
“Now*rp his*r older*r son*r was*r in*r the*r field,*r and*r as*r he*r came*r and*r drew*r near*r to*r the*r house,*r he*r heard*r music*r and*r dancing.*r
And*r he*r called*r one*r of*r the*r servants*r and*r asked*r what*r these*r things*r meant.*r
And*r he*r said*r to*r him,*r ‘Your*r brother*r has*r come,*r and*r your*r father*r has*r killed*r the*r fattened*r calf,*r because*r he*r has*r received*r him*r back*r safe*r and*r sound.’*r
But*r he*r was*r angry*r and*r refused*r to*r go*r in.*r His*r father*r came*r out*r and*r entreated*r him,*r

but*r he*r answered*r his*r father,*r ‘Look,*r these*r many*r years*r I*r have*r served*r you,*r and*r I*r never*r disobeyed*r your*r command,*r yet*r you*r never*r gave*r me*r a*r young*r goat,*r that*r I*r might*r celebrate*r with*r my*r friends.*r
But*r when*r this*r son*r of*r yours*r came,*r who*r has*r devoured*r your*r property*r with*r prostitutes,*r you*r killed*r the*r fattened*r calf*r for*r him!’*r
And*r he*r said*r to*r him,*r ‘Son,*r you*r are*r always*r with*r me,*r and*r all*r that*r is*r mine*r is*r yours.*r
It*r was*r fitting*r to*r celebrate*r and*r be*r glad,*r for*r this*r your*r brother*r was*r dead,*r and*r is*r alive;*r he*r was*r lost,*r and*r is*r found.’”*r
